15.content:
1. Tactical Conquest
One day, the world becomes a tactical RPG where people create factions and solve conflicts with turn based strategy battles in the hope of conquering everyone else. Be careful, as the losers of these battles are at the whim of the winners.

2. Dungeon Escape
You find yourself trapped in a dungeon where you have to gain EXP and avoid traps and harmful items and enemies while escaping the dungeon. Death will reset you at the beginning of the dungeon with all your exp and items lost.

3. Unwilling Campaign
You and your friends are stuck in an RPG world where someone you know is the DM with absolute control.

4. Trapped in a Videogame
You are suddenly trapped in an mysterious RPG game you find and are now the playable character as someone finds the game and starts playing it.
15.title: More Options

choices: And now for something completely different
151.content:
Steven held up the box like a knight, holding aloft his trophy, or remarking upon his great conquest. He was quite tall and thin, often referred to as gangly by those who saw him. Despite being almost 18, his facial hair was still quite patchy, and his complexion wasn't perfect. He kept his brown hair long and tied back in a ponytail, and his female friends agreed that he'd be pretty cute once he left his awkward teen years behind.

Or really fat once his metabolism crashed, given how much he ate and his refusal to work out.

The reaction he received to his news was fairly lackluster.

"... seriously, bro? You brought us out here for this?" Steven's sister, Samantha ("Because Heaven forbid our parents choose a name with a different letter..."), all but rolled her eyes at her brother's purchase. Like her brother, she had brown hair, though of a considerably lighter shade. Puberty had been far kinder to her then to Steven, and it was widely agreed that Sam was one of the top beauties of their high school. In particular, she was considerably more active then her brother, playing for both the volleyball and basketball teams, giving her a trim, tight figure that left many a high school boy dreaming in class.

"This from the girl that owns and has beat every Disgaea game ever made."

"Yeah, I love strategy games. I also like humor. And plot. And story. When has Anatal ever had any of that?"

Steven set the game on the table and cracked a can of coke. "Oh, come on, Sam. The first game was a classic."

"Yeah, the FIRST game," said Jacob, one of the twin's good friends. He was shorter then the two beanpoles he was next to, only standing about 5'5". He kept his curly red hair short, and was a bit on the heavy side. "Seriously, what are they even up to by now? 27?"

"This is game 6, jackass."

"Not helping your case here, dude." This time, the one who spoke was Sylvia. One of Sam's closest friends from the moment the two met in elementary school, she'd gone through the most drastic changes over time out of any of them.

When Steven had met Syl, she'd been an excitable and talkative little girl, gabbing non-stop, always wearing pink dresses and ribbons, and obsessed with everything cute and fuzzy in existence.

And now, she was the most depressing goth who'd ever walked the planet. The only articles of clothing in her closest that weren't black were grey. Her hair, naturally platinum blonde, was dyed black. Her fingernails, her lipstick, everything about her save her skin was black. Most people found her moody or non-responsive, and she generally only opened up to her closest friends in private, like now.

No one in the room was really certain why she'd had such a personality shift in middle school. Sam's running theory was that Sylvia's early development had something to do with it, and even now she was probably the bustiest girl in school, though the heavy sweaters she favored did make it hard to tell.

Sylvia continued, "Honestly, every game after numero uno was just a cheap cash in on the cult following of the first one. What makes you think attempt #: 6 is somehow going to be any different?"

"Well, unlike you lot, I've been doing my research. For starters, "GAMER$" went bankrupt, right?"

"Why no, Steve. We knew nothing of the endless lawsuits and predatory business practices and their multiple failing products, as we don't have the internet in our Amish community."

"Don't be an ass, Jake. Gamer$ had the rights to Anatal, but when they folded, it was bought by Blackstone."

"And who are they?"

"It's the company that was founded by Pan Twardowski and Richard Obsidian."

That got the attention of the other three people in the room. The aforementioned duo had been the creators of the original game, but had been fired by Gamer$ almost immediately after the title launched. Rumors abounded as to why, but the most likely reason was, with their contract with the company coming due, Gamer$ wanted to get rid of them before they had to pay them more. The two had tried for years to purchase the rights from the company, but Gamer$ wouldn't let it go.

Sylvia picked up the non-descript black box. Her voice was more reverent then sarcastic now, and she forgot to keep slouching, stretching out her shirt far more noticeably then before. "So, this is a new Anatal made by the original creators themselves?"

Steven only smiled. "Better. This is a beta copy they sent me to play test."

"Jesus. Who'd you have to blow to score that?"

"Classy, Sam. And no one. I put my name in their draw and won one of the beta copies. And guess what? It has multiplayer."

Jake was already breaking out his lap top. "Well, what the hell are we waiting for?"

*** *** ***

Indeed. What are we waiting for?
151.title: "For the Glory of Anatal!"

choices: And now for something completely different
1512.content:
"We've got a couple more people to hook up with online. Told them we'd be on about nine o'clock, our time. Should give us plenty of time to get you guys set up and grab some food n'stuff before we start."

"Sounds good to me," Jake said as he started to set up a folding table. "We're just doing this in the garage, I'm guessing?"

"Yeah, Dad's still got the basement all tore up, so this is the only spot that's big enough. Sam, could you grab an end of this table?"

Within short order, the garage was set up for the marathon gaming session to follow. The folding tables had been arranged in a square, and a few extension cords allowed them to power up all their machines. Steven brought his tower down from his bedroom, leaving him panting heavily from moving that monster. As he wiped the sweat from his brow, he heard his sister cluck her tongue behind him.

"Seriously? Why can't you just use one of our laptops? That'd have been way easier."

"No way. I want to see this baby at max graphics."

"It's not like you're going to see much of a difference, anyway," Jacob said as he read through the various provided documents. "Says here that this is not the final graphics set. Jesus, these settings. This could halfway cripple my machine as is, and they're trying to make them better."

"What else does it say?" Sylvia asked. She'd just gotten back from running home for her laptop which, despite her monochromatic wardrobe, still remained pink and flowery, much to the private amusement of Samantha.

"Standard NDA stuff. Can discuss on our private site forums, but nowhere else, blah, blah, blah, game is not yet fully balanced, experiment with everything, especially the new multiplayer feature. Honestly, the list goes on and on."

Syl leaned over Jake's shoulder and let out a low whistle. "Wow. Is my comp even going to be able to run this?"

"I got a spare in my truck if yours won't, but it should be fine if you put your graphics to minimum." Steven was unquestionably the tech junkie out of the four, and seemed to have the latest of everything, and often multiples to boot.

"Kay, cool. Is this me over here?" Syl pointed to the sole empty table and began setting up without waiting for an answer. As she set her stuff out on the table, she kept talking. "Not sure if making it so graphically intense is such a good idea. That'll really limit their pool of buyers, won't it?"

"Hard to say. Anatal has always been a blend of RPG and turn based tacticu-holy shit...!" Steve had turned towards Sylvia while speaking, and was greeted with quite a sight. It was already a bit warm in the garage, and undoubtedly would only get worse. Because of this, Sylvia had decided to take off her sweater, and he just so happened to look at precisely the moment she pulled it over her head. Underneath, she'd been wearing a white spaghetti strap top, which did nothing to hide her lacy blue bra or the titanic assets it was trying to restrain. She was firmly an E cup, if not an F, and given her slim build and petite frame, her breasts looked absolutely huge on her.

Sylvia slowly became aware of Steve's unblinking stare, his jaw moving wordlessly. Already regretting her decision, she slowly pulled her sweater in front of herself. She'd been fairly self-conscious of her body for a lot of years by this point, and was quite uncomfortable with just how well endowed she was. Sam had always been telling her to loosen up, but that was easier said then done. She figured she'd be fine around her friends, since she'd always seen Steve and Jake more like brothers, but apparently she could even have an effect on them.

Steven eventually found his voice. The two blushing teens couldn't look at each other as he picked up from where he left off. "A-anyway, as I w-was saying, Anatal has always been a blend of RPG and turn based strategy, so it's kind of a niche market to begin with."

"And that niche market just so happens to have the most powerful PC's on the planet, do they?" Jacob was currently trying to funnel the extension cord to the outlet under the work bench. He grunted and finally let out a sound of triumph as he felt the plug connect. "You might have the latest thing on the market, but my stuff is generally mid-range, at best."

"We got power," Sam said as she walked over and plucked Sylvia's sweater from her hands. Despite the petite woman's wordless protests, she placed it up on the top shelf, well out of her reach. She turned around and mouthed to her, "If you can't get comfortable around them, you can't get comfortable around anybody. Trust me. Relax."

"Besides," she continued aloud, "maybe they'll have better optimization at launch. Alright, now for those of us who haven't played any Anatal games since the third, what do I need to know?"

"Oh, don't worry. Blackstone reset the time line to the end of the first game."

Samantha just rolled her eyes. "Steve, it's been like, six years since I played ANY of the games, let alone the first. And unlike you, I don't replay the original every summer like a religious ritual. Just humor your older sister and give me a rundown of the story."

"You're only older by, like, 19 minutes!"

"Ah, ah, ah, 13 years."

"Oh for... I don't age a quarter of your speed because I was born on February 29th!"

"Um, guys, could we focus a little here? Backstory? Details? Sam's not the only one who needs a refresher," Jake said, eager to avoid the twins wasting most of the night bickering.

"Alright, alright, alright," Steve said, turning towards the other two. "What do you want to hear about first?"
1512.title: A few more players

choices: And now for something completely different
15121.content:
"Story, but try and be brief, dude. The details will be in the game, so keep it to broad strokes."

"I'll try, but I make no promises. Alright, so, the formerly biggest human realm was the Immortal Empire. At the end of the first game, they'd fallen to civil war, and had broken into three chunks.

At the same time, the Gothic kingdom had risen in the west. They'd been a reaver clan of the Halogalanders, and the last ruler of the old Imperial dynasty had given them land and titles if they swore fealty to him. He thought it was a win-win. He'd get a powerful subject to help his wars, a depopulated and poor province would be made productive, and since the Jarl was on the coast, any raiding would happen in his lands instead of Imperial ones.

Of course, what happened was the Goths took the land and told the Emperor to get stuffed. The childless Emperor got himself killed trying to bring them to heel. His death set off the civil war, and the Goths took the lion's share of the Empire for themselves. They even took the ancient Imperial capital, Khorshemish, for their own.

So, in terms of feel, the Goths are medieval Normans, the Halogalanders are the Vikings, and the three Imperial factions are the Byzantine Empire, with some variations between them."

Samantha had to interrupt. "You mean the divine marriage ones, right?"

Steve could only roll his eyes as Sylvia shot a confused glance at Sam. "Oh, of course that's what you'd remember. Yes, the one branch sees themselves as being divinely descended, so they try to keep the line pure."

Sylvia scrunched up her face. "Oh, ew. Why don't I remember that from the game?"

"It only made an appearance in the first game. Gamer$ dropped it from their subsequent titles, and even in the first game, it was only mentioned in passing. Anyway, moving swiftly along, the Empire's implosion actually really helped out the non-human races. In the centuries since humanity showed up on the continent, many of them had been pushed to the brink.

The Orcs especially needed the breathing room. A race of nomadic hunter-gatherers, they'd followed the reindeer herds of Ghurtha for countless generations. Famed archers and spearmen, Orc ambushes were a constant fear for those traveling in the wilds, and their reputation as cannibals was well deserved. That said, they really didn't have the numbers to deal with the vast, organized armies of humanity, and had been pushed almost to extinction. They kind of got a Scottish caveman feel to them, really. I know they used Irish Gaelic for their language.

The Dwarfs had fared far better, overall. Their mountain holds would have been suicide for any army to attack, and the humans figured out pretty quickly that they made far better trading partners then enemies. They're obsessed with perfection, seeking it in everything they do, even if it will kill them. They're really pessimistic too, believing their own god is the cause of all their misfortune and misery. They've got a well deserved rep as a bunch of angry, grumbling drunks. They got a very Slavic feel to them, and I think they used Russian as a stand in for their language.

Then there's the Elves."

Sylvia let out a grin as she checked up on her download. "Oh, I love Anatal's Elves."

Sam looked between her friend and brother. "Really? The hippies?"

"Oh, these aren't hippies," Sylvia said. "They're bloody psychotic. They're a family of interdimensional energy beings, exiled to this world by the rest of their species. The bodies you see are the shells of kidnapped human children, their souls devoured and physical form reshaped to fit the desires of the Elf in question. They can inhabit them for about a millennium before they need a new one, though that timeline can be shortened if they use a lot of magic. And in terms of spell casting, they're second to none."

"Polish, actually." The other three turned towards Jake. "Sorry, looking up details on line."

"But yeah," Steven continued. "The Elves are the very definition of evil, with a capital E. About the only thing that can threaten them one v. one is a dragon. Or another Elf."

Sam frowned a little. "Isn't that a little broken?"

"Oh yeah. It was one of the big weaknesses of the original game. Originally, they weren't supposed to be playable, but Gamer$ forced Obsidian and Twardowski to make them so. Even in the later games, Gamer$ really struggled with their balancing. They're a god-like heavy magic faction in a game where most of the factions have zero magic. Fact is, in the lore, no one can directly threaten the Elves. And in the first game, if you couldn't hire on a dragon, you just had to resign and start a new campaign; there was just no way to beat them without one."

Steven turned and looked at the clock. "Well, I don't want to keep rattling on all night. There's a bunch of new features in the game. They're using a hex based map now, instead of the old squares. The Orcs are properly nomadic now, instead of having settlements. Oh, and they got the new barbarian factions."

"I already like the sound of this," Sam said with a predatory smile.

"I thought you might. They don't have any cities or settlements. Given they have no constant source of gold, they instead hire themselves out to other factions. They can raid or tithe the areas they're in. They also have drastically reduced upkeep to help with survivability, thought Blackstone did say the balancing is a little tricky."

"So how do they recruit new units?"

"It depends. Human barbarians are generally mercs, so you can recruit in human territories. Ogres, on the other hand, are purely nomadic. Their tribal pop slowly increases each round. Bulls with clubs can always be built if you have spare pop, other units need certain loot to be present in the tribe's stockpile. So, given the extreme cliff notes version, any idea what all you want to play? Many factions have multiple playable characters, so we can double up, if we want."

"Oh, I'm definitely going Elf," Sylvia piped up.

"I'm not even surprised by that. Well, what about you two?"

*** *** ***
15121.title: Story, then mechanics

155.content:
1. The Wrong Experience Bar
A normal guy gets a new VR game system with a new RPG game installed in it. However, as he plays through the game, his behavior in the real world begins to change, mirroring the experiences in his game.

2. A Sibling-bonding VR Experience
A boy has a sister with a VR game system and RPG game. The two are not on really good terms with each other. The sister, desiring to improve their relationship, puts the VR system on his head every night when he is asleep, so he can play through her game and begin to understand her interests. Little does she know, this begins to effect his actual behavior in the real world.
155.title: VR Gone Wrong!

1551.content:
"Oh my god oh my god OH MY GOD!" thought Brian as he opened the box containing the new VR headset that has become a worldwide sensation these past few months. "Although it doesn't have many games, if even half of what people have been saying about this is true it's going to be the best most immersive gaming experience of my life!"

Brian hurriedly plugged the headset waiting to see the little blue led light up, sat down on his bed comfortably and put on the headset. The feeling was something out of this world - as if the strongest wind imaginable swept him off his bed and in a second zapped him through space to a different dimension. A swirl of colors and light blinded him when he came to, everything was bright but he slowly got used to it, and looking up saw he had a sort of floating menu in front of him. the menu read:

"Welcome User!

Please state your name."

Brian hesitated for a second, and answered softly "Brian..."

"Welcome Brianne! We here at VRality can't thank you enough for joining our community, and do sincerely hope you will enjoy our world!

Currently only a few games are available, though in the future more will come!

Please tell us which of the following games would you like to play first:

The Land of Mysteria, a thrilling RPG in a magical land full of secrets awaiting only the bravest travelers.

Arena Royale, where combatants large and small face each other in unending battles to claim ultimate victory.

Once Upon a Dream, a game suited for all ages looking to enjoy the wonders of VR in a land where fairy tales are the reality.

?????, *The title of this game is unavailable and any information cannot yet be disclosed.

We await eagerly your choice!"

What will Brian choose to play?
1551.title: The Wrong Experience Bar

choices: A VRMMO would help best, seen it in the stories I have!
A dating sim where a select audience can influence the player
Risk it and openly suggest the idea to your brother
1552.content:
It was a typical afternoon in the Maluable household.

"You're such a bitch!!" "Well, you're an asshole!!"

That is to say, it was host to a screaming match between the two children of the Maluable family. Sam and Jinn Maluable got along like oil and water. Sam was a bit of an introvert with interests in sports, video games, comedy slice of life shows. Jinn was more of an extrovert with interests in fashion, visual novels, and action-packed comic books. As children, they got along well enough but school-life caused them to become highly aggressive toward one another.

What happened to cause this kind of aggression? Lots of little things driving a bigger and bigger wedge between them. This fight is no different, at least, almost no different.

"I'm just asking you to keep quiet, I know you just got dumped but you don't need to scream the FUCKING house down!!" Sam yelled as he stomped back into his room.

"I really liked this guy! So excuse me if I'm a little upset over the fact he dumped me BY TEXT!!!" The only response she got back from this was the sound of a door being slammed. After a few minutes passed Jinn collapsed onto the living room couch, she ran the shouting match through her again and realized that this time it was her fault. Sam did just ask for a bit of quiet, albeit quite curtly but she was the one who started shouting and slinging insults first.

Jinn sighed as she ran a hand down her face.

'It shouldn't have to be like this.' Jinn thought as she looked about the nearly quiet house. Their parents often had to travel for work which left the two teens home alone for the most part. A sudden feeling of loneliness washed over her as she thought about how most of their days after school ended.

"This has to change." Jinn murmured to herself but how? Even if she tried to apologize now, Sam wouldn't take it all that seriously and they don't exactly have any hobbies that could bond over... Wait. Jinn walked over to the games room and rummaged around in the cupboard until she pulled out two VR headsets. Mum and Dad had gotten them as gifts just last month, the tech for these games had improved dramatically over the last couple of years. Even to the point where people could use them while they slept!

info.brief_description: Your life is now an RPG, and it is transforming you.
info.description:
So this is kind of a rework from the 'Learning Magic' interactive.

Our main character's life has now been turned into an RPG in some way but, the rules are weird and never really in his favor.

Basic Rules:
The interactive is basically you making decisions for our characters, the laws of entropy and the big one: The DM-like interface that our hero has to deal with. Doing actions or using items can affect characters stats which can affect their behavior. When making up status effects for objects, they can be outrageous as you like but try have them make sense.

-Try to stay away from making the characters into hardcore criminals: stealing is fine, but don't turn people rape or kill crazy, please.

-Respect the pathway you are contributing to! Don't ignore events for your convience unless they have no affect on what you are trying to write.

-Other than that.....

GO NUTS!
